children.name: to go to a place and take sth from there
get
children.definition: to go to the place where sth is, and bring them back, or tell them to come back :
examples: ▪I’ll get my coat and then we can go.
go (and) get sth
▪Forget the cooking, let’s go get takeout.
get somebody somethingget something for someone
▪Could you get me my keys from the kitchen?
▪I’m going to get myself a beer, does anyone else want one?

children.name: pick up
children.definition: to go to a place where sth is ready for you, and take them with you:đón, nhặt lên
examples: Can you pick some milk up from the shop on your way home?
I’ll pick up the tickets on my way home from work.
Hi, I’ve come to pick up a suit I left on Tuesday.

children.name: collect
children.definition: Britishto go to the place where sth is waiting for you, and bring them back :
examples: ▪I’ve got a parcel to collect from the post office.

children.name: fetch
children.definition: Britishto go to get sth that you need and bring them back :
examples: Where’s your mug? Go and fetch it.
Martha fetched a towel from the bathroom.
fetch sb sth
Could you fetch me a screwdriver?

children.name: to go to a place and take sb from there
get
children.definition: to go to the place where sb is, and bring them back, or tell them to come back:
examples: ▪ Dinner’s ready. Can you get Jo?
▪ I’ve got to get the kids in a few minutes.
go (and) get sb :
▪ Go and get your father. He’s in the garden.

children.name: pick up
children.definition: to meet sb at a particular place in order to take them somewhere in a car, bus etc: đến đón
examples: She picks her daughter up from school every day at four.
I told Virginia I’d pick her up about 8:00.
I arranged to pick up Mr Clarke and take him to his accommodation.
Do you want me to come back and pick you guys up?
Nadia will pick you up at the airport.
‘Where’s Diana?’ ‘She just left to pick up the kids from school.’

children.name: collect
children.definition: British to go to the place where sb is waiting for you, and bring them back: đến đón
examples: ▪ I’m at the station. Can you come and collect me?
▪ We’ll have to eat later, I’m collecting Grandma from the hospital this evening.
▪ Her father sent a taxi to collect her from the hotel.
▪ If the last bus has left, I’ll collect you.

children.name: fetch
children.definition: Britishto go to get sb that you need and bring them back :đến tìm, đi tìm, đi kiếm
examples: Jim’s gone to fetch the police.
I have to fetch my mother from the station.

children.name: call for
children.definition: sbto go to a place in order to collect sbđón ai
examples: I'll call for you at eight.

children.name: to take sb with you to a place
carry
children.definition: to take sb/sth from one place to another, by holding it in your hands, lifting it on your back etc: mang, cầm, bê, vác
examples: A porter helped me carry my bags.
Gina was carrying a small bunch of flowers.
Let me carry that for you.
carry sth out of/around etc sth
Angela carried the child in her arms.
Jack carried his grandson up the stairs.
The women have to carry water from the well to the village.
I’ve been carrying this tape-recorder around with me all day.
carry sth to sb/sth
The waiter carried our drinks to the table.

children.name: take
children.definition: /teɪk/  to have sb with you when you go to another place, often paying for them or being responsible for them:dẫn , đưa aitake sb to/out/into/home etc:▪ I can’t stop, I’ve got to take the kids to school. ▪ She was taken straight into the emergency room when we arrived. ▪ Would you like me to take you home?take sb with you▪ Take the dogs with you if you’re going for a walk.take sb playing/swimming/etcWill you take me swimmingtomorrow?

children.name: bring
children.definition: /brɪŋ/  if sbbringsa person to the placewhere you are, they have that person with them when they come:dẫn theo, chở theo
examples: ▪ We’ve brought someone to see you!
bring sb to/into/out/home etc:
▪ When are you going to bring him in for his injections?
▪ The only time we use the VCR is when they bring Joey to our house.
bring sb with you
▪ I hope he hasn’t brought his brother with him.
▪ Is it okay if I bring some clothes with me to wash?

children.name: transfer
children.definition: formalto move from one place to another, or to move sth from one place to another
examples: transfer (from sth) to sth
The exhibition transfers to York City Art Gallery on 23rd January.
transfer sth (from sth) to sth
Transfer the meat to warm plates.
She transferred her gunfromits shoulder holstertoher handbag.
Police are investigating how £20 million was illegally transferredfrom/out ofthe Trust's bank account.
transfer[C or U] B2 the process by which sth is moved from one place to another
transfer of
the transfer of information
transfer to
electronic data transfer

children.name: to take sth with you to a place
bear
children.definition: formalorwrittento carry sth, especially sth important:mang đến
examples: A messenger arrived, bearing a letter from the ambassador.
At the head of the procession a group of dark-suited men bore the coffin into the church.
The wedding guests arrived, bearing gifts.
The US Constitution states that the people have a right tobear arms.

children.name: carry
children.definition: to take sb/sth from one place to another, by holding it in your hands, lifting it on your back etc: mang, cầm, bê, vác
examples: A porter helped me carry my bags.
Gina was carrying a small bunch of flowers.
Let me carry that for you.
carry sth out of/around etc sth
Angela carried the child in her arms.
Jack carried his grandson up the stairs.
The women have to carry water from the well to the village.
I’ve been carrying this tape-recorder around with me all day.
carry sth to sb/sth
The waiter carried our drinks to the table.

children.name: tote
children.definition: US informalto carry sth, especially sth heavy or awkward regularly:váctheo, mang theo
examples: My job was to tote their golf bags and wash their cars.
a gun-toting cowboy
Kids have to tote heavy textbooks around.
She usually toted the baby around in a backpack.
The building was surrounded with bodyguards toting sub-machine guns .
Gun -toting security men were posted at all the entrances.

children.name: take
children.definition: /teɪk/  to have something with you when you go to another place: dẫn khỏi
examples: ▪ Don’t forget to take your keys.
▪ I’ve started taking a packed lunch to work to save money.
take sb/sth to/out/into/home etc: dẫn ai/cái gì tới/ra khỏi/vào/dẫn về nhà
▪ ‘Where’s Dan?’ ‘He’s taken the car to the garage.’
▪ I can’t stop, I’ve got to take the kids to school.
▪ She was taken straight into the emergency room when we arrived.
▪ Would you like me to take you home?
▪ Are we allowed to take library books home with us?
take somebody something: đưa ai cái gì
▪ I took Alice a cup of tea.
take sb/sth with you: đem theo cái gì
▪ Did he take the camera with him?
▪ Take the dogs with you if you’re going for a walk.

children.name: lug
children.definition: /schlepUS  informal to carry something heavy with difficulty: kéo theo
examples: We lugged our suitcases up the hotel steps.
I’ve got enough to carry without lugging your bags as well.
They lugged the mail in heavy canvas bags into the building.

children.name: bring
children.definition: /brɪŋ/  if sb brings a person or thing to the place where you are, they have that person or thing with them when they come: đem theo
examples: ▪ I brought my Nikes - they’re about the only decent shoes I have.
▪ We’ve brought someone to see you!
bring somebody to/into/out/home etc: đem theo ai tới/vào/ra/dẫn ai về nhà
▪ Everyone’s bringing a bit of food and a bottle to the party.
▪ When are you going to bring him in for his injections?
▪ The only time we use the VCR is when they bring Joey to our house.
▪ I brought some work home and tried to get it finished in the evening.
bring somebody something: đưa ai cái gì
▪ Robert asked the waiter to bring him the check.
bring somebody/something with you: ai dẫn ai theo
▪ I hope he hasn’t brought his brother with him.
▪ Is it okay if I bring some clothes with me to wash?

children.name: cart
children.definition: /kɑːʳt/  informal to carry sth that is awkward or heavy: vác, xách
examples: cart something down/out etc
Madge picked up the box and carted it out to the back yard.
I’m not going to cart your shopping around all afternoon.

children.name: to go to a place and take sth from there
get
children.definition: /get/  to go to the place where something is, and bring them back :
examples: đi lấy, đi kiếm, đi tìm ( và mang nó lại )
▪ I’ll get my coat and then we can go.
get somebody something : get something for someone:lấy cho ai cái gì
▪ Could you get me my keys from the kitchen?
▪ I’m going to get myself a beer, does anyone else want one?
go (and) get something:
▪ Forget the cooking, let’s go get takeout.
getverbgetting,got,gotorUSgottenOBTAIN
[ T ] to go somewhere and bring back someone or something
I must just get the washingin.
[ + two objects ]Can I get you a drink?

children.name: pick up
children.definition: to go to a place where something is ready for you, and take them with you:đến lấy, chở
examples: pick somebody/something up:
▪ Do you want me to come back and pick you guys up?
▪ Nadia will pick you up at the airport.
▪ Can you pick some milk up from the shop on your way home?
pick up somebody/something:
▪ ‘Where’s Diana?’ ‘She just left to pick up the kids from school.’
▪ I’ll pick up the tickets on my way home from work.
▪ Hi, I’ve come to pick up a suit I left on Tuesday.
picksb/sthupphrasal verb[ M ]COLLECT
to collect, or to go and get, someone or something
_When you're in town could you pick up the books I ordered?
_Whose turn is it to pick the children up after school?
_The crew of the sinking tanker were picked up (= saved from the sea) by helicopter.

children.name: collect
children.definition: UKto go to the place where sth is ready for you, and bring them back:đên lấy, đến nhận, đến thu, đến gom
examples: I’m at the station. Can you come and collect me?
We’ll have to eat later, I’m collecting Grandma from the hospital this evening.
I’ve got a parcel to collect from the post office.
Your shoes will be repaired and ready for you to collect on Thursday.
collection[C or U] B2 the act of taking something from a place
The photos will beready forcollection on Tuesday afternoon.
Which day is the rubbish collection?
UKThere are three collections a day from the post box on the corner.
Garbage collections are made every Tuesday morning.
Please collect your purchases from the customercollection point.

children.name: fetch
children.definition: /fetʃ/ Britishto go to get someone or something that you need and bring them back :
examples: đi tìm, đi lấy ( cái gì và mang nó lại vì đang cần đến )
▪ Where’s your mug? Go and fetch it.
▪ Martha fetched a towel from the bathroom.
fetch somebody something: tìm về cho ai cái gì
▪ Could you fetch me a screwdriver?
fetchverbGET tìm về; đem về/ đón ( ai )
[ T ] to go to another place to get something or someone and bring them back
_[ + two objects ]Could you fetch me my glasse/fetch my glassesforme from the other room, please?
_I have to fetch my mother from the station.

children.name: to not take sb/sth with you to a place
leave
children.definition: to not take sb with you when you go, either intentionally or by accident
examples: leave sb in/with etc
Why don't you leave the kidswithme on Friday?
Are you leaving the kids with Grandma on Saturday?
Shelefther sonin the care ofa friend.
leave sb to do sth
He left Ruth to find her own way home.
Students wereleft totheirown devices(= left alone and allowed to do whatever they wanted )for long periods.
leave sb for dead
The girl had been attacked and left for dead.
leave behind[M] B2
He departed for Washington, leaving the children behind with their mother.
He was forced to leave the country, leaving behind his wife and children.
leave[T + object + -ing verb]C1if you leave sb doing sth, when you go away they are still doing it
I left the children watchingtelevision.

children.name: leave
children.definition: to not take sth with you when you go, either intentionally or by accident
examples: leave sth in/with etc
As soon as I’d shut the door, I realized I’d left the keys inside.
leave behind[M] B2
I think I might have left my wallet behind.
Did anybody leave a jacket behind last night?
We left in a hurry and I must have left my keys behind.
leave[T + object + -ing verb]C1if you leave sth doing sth, when you go away they are still doing it
He left the energy running .

children.name: to leave sb/sth swh after take them with you
drop off
children.definition: to take sth to a particular place,usually in a car, and leave them there, especially on your way to another place :
examples: We dropped our luggage off at the hotel and went sightseeing.

children.name: drop
children.definition: to take sb to a particular place,usually in a car, and leave them there, especially on your way to another place :
examples: Just drop me here – I can walk the rest of the way.
drop sb at sth
She dropped Johnny at the school gates at about 8:30.
I dropped himatthe library and went shopping.
drop off[M]
I’ll drop you off on my way home.
They dropped meoffat the main entrance.
